We cannot allow politics to prevent progress in reforming our immigration system, and that’s why a bipartisan effort is the only way forward if we’re going to find a permanent solution to fixing our immigration system and helping those families at the border.

That means more resources to process asylum claims more efficiently, more immigration judges & social workers, & investment in border security to stop cartels from taking advantage of our immigration system.

If we’re going to fix our broken immigration system, we need a comprehensive solution that ensures both a fair pathway to legal citizenship for immigrants and resources for border security and enforcement.

It is clear that we have not invested enough in the security of our border or the safety of those legally trying to immigrate to our country. I saw firsthand the challenges facing Customs and Border Protection Officers who don’t have the resources they need to do their jobs.
I saw people seeking asylum in long lines, often up to 15 days, and were waiting desperately because there weren’t enough resources to process their claims efficiently.

The people I met in custody put themselves at incredible risk to escape violence, aren’t sure what their future holds, & are being held in poor conditions. Yet, I could still see hope in their eyes. It made me understand more than ever we must come together to find a solution.
I came away from my trip to the border acutely aware of how broken our immigration policy is. I also came away with a commitment to be part of the answer to fix our broken immigration system.
(Thread) My Visit to the Border in McAllen, TX, and the solutions we need to fix our immigration system:

UPDATE FROM THE #BORDER:

Ports of entry are so backed up. Clearly not putting enough resources toward processing asylum claims.

Instead of waiting in long lines, families risk crossing the Rio Grande here, 100s of ft wide. Here see a little girl's hat in mud near the riverbank. pic.twitter.com/1j9xlonJyd

UPDATE FROM THE BORDER:

There's not enough resources here for border officers to process/care for people & families.

People legally seeking asylum waiting in long lines (up to 15 days) just to get through ports of entry.

The system is clearly broken.

More updates coming.

.@BetsyDeVosED will have to answer for her department’s inaction surrounding borrower defense in @EdLaborCmte. Ultimately, we want to find the best way forward to help our students & hold predatory schools accountable. I’m hopeful we’ll make progress towards that goal this week.

.@SenatorDurbin and I introduced a Congressional Review Act to overturn @BetsyDevosED’s harmful Borrower Defense rule and force her and her Department to finally review and repay the claims of 200,000+ defrauded American students. https://susielee.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-susie-lee-sen-dick-durbin-lead-congressional-effort-overturn-damaging-devos …

Most importantly, as the 2016 rule has been slow-walked by @BetsyDeVosED, over 220,000 borrower defense claims have been left pending, some for 3+ years. This includes 1000’s of veterans, working parents, and young students just trying to get an education and better themselves.

The moment @BetsyDeVosED took over, she delayed implementation of the 2016 rule--delays that were found illegal in court. 

She’s attempted to implement a weaker borrower defense rule that ultimately undermines the original purpose of borrower defense--to help defrauded students.

The 2016 Borrower Defense Rule, in part, included:

✅Clear processes for how to file claims
✅Empower @usedgov to forgive loans quickly
✅Hold financially irresponsible for-profit schools accountable
✅Ban schools from misleading students to signing unfair arbitration agreements

After Corinthian’s collapse, the Obama admin updated the 1995 Rule b/c it “provided little detail on how borrowers could submit, and how @usedgov would adjudicate claims.” 

In 2016, they issued the new defense rule--estimated to provide $17 billion of relief to students.

The rule rarely had to be used until the major collapse of the predatory for-profit college, Corinthian College. Corinthian’s collapse left an estimated 350,000 students with worthless degrees and a mountain of student debt, the loans of which they couldn’t use. (3/9)

The original Borrower Defense Rule was implemented as a provision in the 1995 High Education Act to establish how student loan borrowers can receive forgiveness when defrauded by their higher ed. Institution. (2/9)

This Thursday, @EdLaborCmte will question @BetsyDeVosED on @usedgov’s inaction in upholding the Borrower Defense Rule, created to protect students from predatory #4profit schools & help defrauded students seek loan forgiveness. Before then, let’s set the record straight. THREAD:

I’m so glad I was able to help Sandy Valley residents protect their right to reasonable food access. Solving problems like this is exactly why I came to Congress. 

Read more about our efforts here: https://susielee.house.gov/media/press-releases/problem-solved-rep-lee-helps-sandy-valley-general-store-secure-approval-snap …

Shortly after, my office was notified that the store was reevaluated & approved as an official SNAP-retailer!

Bottom line: no reasonable person should expect a family on a limited budget to travel 38 miles roundtrip every time they need groceries. I’m glad @USDA recognized that.

Three weeks ago, I wrote to @SecretarySonny requesting that the store should be reevaluated because the area clearly has significantly limited access to food with a population that heavily relies on affordable food.

Without this store, residents who rely on SNAP need to travel NINETEEN miles to the next-closest SNAP-retailer to buy food. 

Two problems with that: 

1️⃣1 out of 3 Sandy Valley residents relies on SNAP.

2️⃣There is incredibly limited public transportation in Sandy Valley.

In August, the Sandy Valley General Store’s SNAP retailer application was denied, meaning residents could no longer use their SNAP benefits to shop there. @USDA's reason: the store wasn't in an area w/ “significantly limited access to food.” @8NewsNow https://www.8newsnow.com/news/financial-struggles-cause-sandy-valley-general-store-owners-to-close-doors-owners-hope-to-regroup-reopen/ …

✅PROBLEM SOLVED✅

After months of uncertainty, the Sandy Valley General Store was approved by @USDA as an authorized SNAP retailer.

This is a big deal & a lesson on the realities of limited food access in rural areas. How did we get to this point & why does it matter? THREAD:

Since my first day in Congress, I have made it clear that I will fight any and every effort that threatens Nevadans’ access to quality, affordable health care, and I will not stop now.

We are talking about the very real consequences people face if Congress refuses to act. Every American and most members of Congress agree that we need to do something about the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs.
That’s not a choice that any person, or family, should have to make in this country. That’s why we are fighting so hard to lower drug prices and protect the #AffordableCareAct from being torn apart.

… and now they have to make the choice between getting their medicine and buying groceries, fixing their car, or paying rent on time. Last year, one in three Americans did not fill a prescription due to high prices.
Nearly every week, I hear from my constituents about how the price of their insulin, their heart medication, or their kid’s inhaler jumped 50, 75, and sometimes over 100 percent …
There are very few issues in our state and country that are as important as making health care more affordable and accessible - especially when it comes to lowering the cost of prescription drugs.
I had a roundtable discussion w/ @RepHorsford @YvannaCancela @HCAN @BattleBornProg on what we need to do to reduce prescription drug prices and protect the #ACA. pic.twitter.com/1ScSi5tOY2

It’s clear that all of you in this room are committed to doing just that, and I’m here to tell you that I’m with you every step of the way.
The bottom line is we need Congress and every elected official to commit to our communities and to the American people, not to special interests.

Opioid abuse doesn’t care if you live in a red state or a blue state or a purple state, and addiction does not care about the D or R next to your name ... It’s immune to partisanship and socioeconomic status.

Well, I did something about it to get the ball rolling in Congress. The House passed my bill to increase funding for the Drug-Free Communities Program, which directly invests in local community efforts to combat opioid abuse.

There are a number of ways to prevent and reduce opioid abuse, addiction, and death. The problem is that our communities--like southern Nevada and our rural communities—just don’t have the resources or the funding to implement the solutions that we know work.

Opioid addiction is hitting our veteran population harder than any other, and it’s largely because of how our country has decided to treat them--by throwing prescription painkiller after prescription painkiller at them rather than giving them comprehensive medical treatment.
At least one Nevadan loses their life to opioids every day, & that’s especially painful b/c we know it’s preventable. And for no group of people is that more true than for our veterans.
We must treat opioid addiction like the public health crisis that it is. It is now the leading cause of accidental deaths in the US.
I’m about to speak at the 2019 Opioid Abuse Prevention Summit, hosted by @NVPublicHealth. Stay tuned for live updates on what we need to do to tackle this epidemic. pic.twitter.com/kKU6NhKj8g

I was elected to address the problems facing our community through common sense solutions, & that begins w/ cleaning up corruption in our gov’t & making public servants actually serve the public again.

5/5 I’m committed to working with stakeholders and constituents to find the best possible solutions to fix a broken system that keeps medication out of reach of those who need it.
4/5 Our discussion was the first of many as we continue to work together to make prescription drugs affordable. No one should have to choose between groceries and their life-sustaining prescriptions.

3/5 Today’s roundtable was an opportunity for me to listen and learn from organizations that are on the ground every day serving Nevadans who struggle to access the vital medication they oftentimes depend on to stay alive.

2/5 Last year, 24% of Americans did not fill out prescriptions due to high costs, and many Americans are not taking recommended dosages in order to make their medication last longer. Let that sink in.

1/5 Today, I hosted a roundtable with @AARPNV, Nevada @ActiveRetirees, @Culinary226 Health Fund, @NVHospitals, @BattleBornProg, and @ProtectOurCare on finding solutions to lower the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs. pic.twitter.com/FBFK1hsIAS

Nevada's classrooms are the most overcrowded in the country. 

We need to pass the The Rebuilding America’s Schools Act with my provision to tackle overcrowding. 

We need to make education a national priority. http://bit.ly/2L8yCPc

Between 2005-17, Nevada’s public schools haven't received the federal funding we expect:

Title 1 funding gap: $2.2 Billion
IDEA Special Education funding gap: $2 Billion

My bill, the Keep our PACT Act, closes these gaps & secures the federal education funding NV deserves.

Remember, at the start of this school year we had 750 teacher vacancies in @ClarkCountySch. We can't just say education is a priority, we have to back it up w/ action.

My bill, the Keep Our PACT Act, fully funds Title I schools & IDEA special ed. to help fill these vacancies.

We stick together through tragedy. #VegasStrong #ElPasoStrong https://bit.ly/2ojHzMC
5/5 Let them know they are supported and that our community sticks together when times get tough. We are and will always be #VegasStrong.

4/5 Our community is incomplete without their dedication to our health and safety—and for that I thank them deeply. In the coming days, reach out to your friends, your family, and your neighbors affected by what happened on that day.

3/5 No one embodies that identity more than our first responders on the scene minutes after the shooting, along with the nurses, doctors, and hospital staff working day and night to care for the countless victims injured that night.

2/5 Since that day, I have seen our city come together in a way that only a strong community can in supporting the victims and their families. Our unity made it clear that ‘Vegas Strong’ is not a catchphrase, it’s a part of our identity.

1/5 Two years ago, our community experienced a tragedy unlike any we have faced before. #1October, 2017, is a day that no Nevadan will forget. The fear, the trauma, the grief that engulfed our city can’t be measured. pic.twitter.com/C2IIXD4e4o
